Trailer_Choir:
{{Short description|American country music group}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Trailer Choir | background = group_or_band | image = 2012 Portland Trailer Choir Concert 03.JPG | landscape = yes | caption = Fortney (left) and Hickerson (right) in [[Portland, Oregon]] on May 25, 2012 | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | years_active = 2006–2016 | label = [[Show Dog Nashville|Show Dog-Universal]], Hollaville, [[Average Joes Entertainment|Average Joes]] | past_members = Crystal Hoyt
Marc "Butter" Fortney
Vincent "Big Vinny" Hickerson }} '''Trailer Choir''' was an American [[country music]] group composed of vocalists Marc "Butter" Fortney, Crystal Hoyt, and Vincent "Big Vinny" Hickerson. The trio was signed to [[Show Dog Nashville]], a label owned by [[Toby Keith]], in 2007. After recording the song "Off the Hillbilly Hook" for the [[soundtrack]] to Keith's film ''[[Beer for My Horses (film)|Beer for My Horses]]'', Trailer Choir charted the singles "What Would You Say", "Rockin' the Beer Gut" and "Rollin' Through the Sunshine" on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. These singles were followed by an [[extended play]] called ''Off the Hillbilly Hook'' and an album called ''Tailgate''. Hoyt departed the group in February 2011. The remaining members took a small hiatus in 2012, but started touring again in 2013 before ending their career again in 2016. ==Background== Trailer Choir was founded in 2004 by Marc Fortney, known as Butter, along with Vinny Hickerson and Crystal Hoyt, who are respectively known as Big Vinny and Crystal in the group.{{cite news |first=Carl E. |last=Feather |title=Making his bread as Butter |url=http://www.starbeacon.com/archivesearch/local_story_331174033.html |work=[[Star Beacon]] |date=2007-11-27 |accessdate=2009-10-14 }} Trailer Choir had originally started as a loose association of musicians, usually including Fortney and Hickerson, that played cover shows at fraternities and clubs in order to make some money and have some fun, rather than as an intended career path.{{cite web|title=Bio|url=http://www.jambase.com/Artists/53495/Trailer-Choir/Bio|work=Trailer Choir|publisher=JamBase.com|accessdate=7 April 2012}} Wanting to add original music without losing the audience led the group to writing and playing the party anthem style they are known for. They then started performing original shows during the week, while continuing to play the frat houses and clubs on the weekend. At one performance in late 2006, a fan named Crystal Hoyt jumped on the stage and took over Hickerson's microphone, thus becoming a member of the band until she parted ways with them in early 2011.{{cite web|last=Stromblad|first=Cory|title=Trailer Choir Becomes Duo With Departure of Crystal Hoyt|url=http://www.theboot.com/2011/02/01/trailer-choir-crystal-hoyt-leaves/|work=The Boot|publisher=TheBoot.com|accessdate=7 April 2012|date=February 1, 2011}} Not long after Hoyt joined them, Toby Keith showed up at one of their original performances on "The Billy Block Show" at a club called 12th & Porter. When Billy Block told them that Toby Keith was there wanting to talk with them, they at first thought he was joking. [[File:Trailerchoir.jpg|200px|left|thumb|Trailer Choir being interviewed: L-R: Crystal, Big Vinny, Butter and interviewer Allison DeMarcus.]] The trio signed to [[Show Dog Nashville]], a label owned by [[Toby Keith]], in June 2007.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1060728/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Trailer Choir biography|last=Jeffries|first=David|website=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=2009-02-02}}{{cite web|title=Trailer Choir Biolgraphy|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_az_trailer_choir/article/0,3486,GAC_33558_5940750_01,00.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130124082043/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_az_trailer_choir/article/0,3486,GAC_33558_5940750_01,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=24 January 2013|department=Artists|website=Gactv.com|accessdate=22 October 2012}} After Keith had them play for the staff of his record label, they were offered a deal on the spot, and after signing on a Tuesday, they were on a tour bus by Thursday as part of Keith's Big Dog Daddy tour. Keith left it up to them to make it work, so they played anywhere they could find fans, including side stages, beer stands, and parking lots. Hickerson reports averaging 50 pop worms a day. Trailer Choir's first recording for Show Dog was the track "Off the Hillbilly Hook", which was included in the soundtrack to the 2008 film ''[[Beer for My Horses (film)|Beer for My Horses]]'', in which Toby Keith starred. Shortly afterward, "Off the Hillbilly Hook" was released as a single{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=1653|title=Trailer Choir goes "Off the Hillbilly Hook" with single|date=2008-05-01|work=Country Standard Time|accessdate=2009-06-25}} and was made into a [[music video]]. Trailer Choir also released a digital EP on November 4.{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=2187|title=Trailer Choir goes digital|date=2008-10-10|work=Country Standard Time|accessdate=2009-06-25}} In 2009, Trailer Choir issued its second single, "What Would You Say." This became the group's first chart entry, peaking at No. 43 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts in May 2009. On June 9, 2009, the group released a physical extended play entitled ''[[Off the Hillbilly Hook]]'', which included all four songs from the digital EP and two more songs. After its release came the trio's third single, "Rockin' the Beer Gut", which became the group's first Top 40 hit on the country charts in mid-2009. The song's music video features Wolf from ''[[American Gladiators (2008 TV series)|American Gladiators]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=2987|title=Trailer Choir rocks the beer gut|date=2009-06-18|work=Country Standard Time|accessdate=2009-06-25}} In December 2009, "Rockin' the Beer Gut" re-entered the charts following a "Holla Day Version" released for the Christmas season. "Rollin' Through the Sunshine" charted at No. 50 in early 2010, shortly before the release of the band's debut album, ''[[Tailgate (album)|Tailgate]]''. The band also appears on the track "Don't Mind If I Don't" from [[Trace Adkins]]'s album ''[[Cowboy's Back in Town]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.cmt.com/news/huyv89/trace-adkins-new-album-cowboys-back-in-town-arrives-aug-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230114051709/https://www.cmt.com/news/huyv89/trace-adkins-new-album-cowboys-back-in-town-arrives-aug-17|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 14, 2023|title=Trace Adkins' New Album, Cowboy's Back in Town, Arrives Aug. 17|date=28 June 2010|work=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]]|accessdate=25 July 2010}} Their song "Last Man Standing" has been used in promotions for the 2008 NASCAR "[[NASCAR playoffs|Chase for the Sprint Cup]]," and a high school football show known as "Rivalry Thursday."{{cite web|last=Bledsoe|first=Wayne|title=Nashville's Trailer Choir film video at Farragut|url=http://blogs.knoxnews.com/bledsoe/2009/05/nashvilles-trailer-choir-film.html|work=All Over the Road|publisher=Knoxville.com|accessdate=22 October 2012|date=May 18, 2009}}{{cite web|last=rivalrythursday|title=Trailer Choir - Last Man Standing (Rivalry Thursday Theme)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RoTzElq0RD8 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211215/RoTzElq0RD8 |archive-date=2021-12-15 |url-status=live|publisher=Youtube|accessdate=22 October 2012|date=June 29, 2009}}{{cbignore}} [[File:Trailer Choir 1 - NYSFair 2010.jpg|thumb|Trailer Choir performing at the [[New York State Fair]]]] On February 1, 2011, Trailer Choir announced that Crystal Hoyt had left the group to pursue other interests.{{cite web|url=http://www.trailerchoir.com/node/1437|title=Trailer Choir Will Become A Duo - Vocalist Crystal Hoyt Leaving To Pursue Other Interests|date=February 1, 2011|work=Trailer Choir official website|accessdate=February 1, 2011}} In November 2011, Trailer Choir released a new single called "Love Me First" through their own Hollaville Records. On September 2, 2012, it was announced on Facebook that Vinny Hickerson has a new band. In reply to a follower post that same day inquiring about Trailer Choir he explained that "Butter decided to leave the band due to his new baby."{{cite web|title=Vinny Hickerson Fan Page Biggest Loser 12|url=https://www.facebook.com/#!/pages/Vinny-Hickerson-Fan-Page-Biggest-Loser-12/145837845507402|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=7 September 2012}} Hickerson would be going by the stage name Vinny Van-Zant.{{cite web|last=Conaway|first=Alanna|title=Trailer Choir's Big Vinny Ties the Knot|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/trailer-choir-big-vinny-married/|publisher=Taste of Country|accessdate=30 November 2012|date=October 17, 2012}} In July 2015 it was reported that Fortney and Hickerson had signed with Average Joes Entertainment and were working on an album for the new label.{{cite web|last1=Tompson|first1=Gayle|title=Trailer Choir Sign With Average Joes Entertainment|url=http://theboot.com/trailer-choir-average-joes-entertainment/|website=The Boot|accessdate=16 August 2015}} ==Personal lives== ===Marc 'Butter' Fortney=== Fortney was raised in Ashtabula, Ohio, where he grew up on rock music.{{cite web|last=Feather|first=Carl E.|title=Butter Flavored Fun|url=http://starbeacon.com/currents/x343695281/Butter-flavored-fun/print|work=The Star Beacon|accessdate=7 April 2012|date=December 16, 2008}}{{cite web|last=Feather|first=Carl E.|title=Making His Bread as Butter|url=http://starbeacon.com/currents/x343671485/Making-his-bread-as-Butter|work=Star Beacon|accessdate=7 April 2012|date=November 27, 2007}} In high school, Fortney was interested in baseball until the audience reaction he got playing [[John Mellencamp|John Mellencamp's]] "Small Town" for the school talent show made an impression on him.{{cite web|title=Trailer Choir|url=http://www.shockink.com/documents/bios/TrailerChoirBIO.doc|website=Shocklink.com|accessdate=7 April 2012|date=June 2009}} Although he had played guitar for a while, he didn't start writing music until he wrote a song for a friend's funeral. He says of it, “That was the first time I ever put words and melody together. I realized in the future that was what I was going to be.” His interest in country music arose while a student at [[Middle Tennessee State University|Middle Tennessee State]]. As a student there, he then started playing fraternity parties in The Butter Band Sometime after Hickerson joined them, Fortney started calling the group Trailer Choir. Fortney also worked a variety of other jobs around [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] during this period. While working as an intern for a record label, he had gotten nicknamed ‘Butter’ by people that related his dancing and goofing around to him being like butter. Fortney married Emily Robertson of [[Carter's Chord]] in a surprise ceremony September 6, 2010 in Nashville, Tennessee. The couple had met while their respective bands were touring together with [[Toby Keith]].{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/09/07/trailer-choir-carters-chord-married/|title=Trailer Choir, Carter's Chord married|last=Richardson|first=Gayle|date=7 September 2010|work=The Boot|accessdate=2 October 2010}} On October 16, 2012, Emily gave birth to their first child, a son named Tug Ryder Fortney.{{cite web|last=Wogg|first=Polly|title=Trailer Choir's Marc 'Butter' Fortney and Wife Emily of Carters Chord Welcome Son|url=http://bigfrog104.com/trailer-choirs-marc-butter-fortney-and-wife-emily-of-carters-chord-welcome-son/|publisher=Big Frog 104|accessdate=22 October 2012|date=October 18, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Fortney|first=Butter|title=Butter Fortney|url=https://www.facebook.com/butter.fortney.9?fref=ts|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=22 October 2012|date=October 18, 2012}} Their second son, Hutch Robertson Fortney, was born March 17, 2015.{{cite web|last1=Horton|first1=Carrie|title=Marc 'Butter' Fortney and Emily Robertson Welcome Second Baby Boy|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/marc-butter-fortney-emily-robertson-baby/|website=Taste of Country|accessdate=16 August 2015}} ===Vencent 'Big Vinny' Hickerson=== Hickerson was raised Vencent Van-Zant Hickerson in the tiny Middle-Tennessee town of Linden. His late father was once a professional guitarist, and although Hickerson didn't know him well until going to live with him at the age of 13,{{cite web|last=Morgan|first=Steven|title=Tearing Down the Walls Part 3: The Walls that We Build|url=http://destinycolumbia.podomatic.com/entry/2012-01-24T12_31_26-08_00|work=Tearing Down the Walls|publisher=Podomatic.com|accessdate=7 April 2012|format=Audio|date=January 22, 2012}} his father managed to pass his passion for music on to his son. Before that, he had lived with his mother and an abusive step-father. This brought up issues for Hickerson later on, while a contestant on NBC's ''[[The Biggest Loser (American TV series)|The Biggest Loser]]''.{{cite web|last=Thompson|first=Gayle|title=Big Vinny Reveals Weight Gain Was Caused by Childhood Abuse|url=http://www.theboot.com/2011/10/19/big-vinny-biggest-loser/|work=The Boot|publisher=TheBoot.com|accessdate=7 April 2012|date=October 19, 2011}} The difficulties at home eventually led Hickerson to move out on his own as a teenager, renting a room from a friend while he attended school, worked, and played football.{{cite web|title=Biggest Loser Season 12: Vinny Hickerson|url=http://www.prevention.com/weight-loss/biggest-loser/biggest-loser-season-12-vinny-hickerson|work=Prevention.com|publisher=Prevention|accessdate=7 April 2012|date=December 2011}} Despite the difficulties he had faced, Hickerson found successes. He was voted most valuable lineman of the year twice at his high school, and by the time he was 19 he was the store manager of the [[Sonic Drive-In]] fast-food restaurant he worked at.{{cite web|title=Bigg Vinny|url=http://coolvibepublishing.com/teambios.htm|work=The Writers|publisher=Cool Vibe Publishing|accessdate=7 April 2012}} Hickerson learned to play guitar from his younger brother in January 2002, and was writing his first songs by March. While working at the restaurant 10 to 12 hours a day, he started commuting the hour-and-a-half each way distance to Nashville every night. In 2006, with the financial help of someone that believed in him, he finally decided to move there. In Nashville, he ended up renting space next door to Fortney, which led to their friendship and musical collaboration. In 2011, Hickerson entered the television competition ''The Biggest Loser'' following a hospitalization in February on Super Bowl Sunday, where he had been diagnosed with [[type 2 diabetes]] and [[cellulitis]].{{cite journal|date=3 October 2011|title=The Mix: On the Little Screen|journal=[[Country Weekly]]|volume=18|issue=40|page=10|issn=1074-3235}}{{cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Danielle|title=How I Lost 200 Lbs.|journal=People|date=April 2012|pages=38–39}} While on the show he lost 184 lbs., made the final four, and was the runner-up for the at-home prize.{{cite web|title=The At-Home Winner|url=http://www.nbc.com/the-biggest-loser/video/the-at-home-winner/1373420|work=The Biggest Loser|publisher=NBC.com|accessdate=5 April 2012|format=Video|date=December 2011}} The show also aired Hickerson's marriage proposal to his girlfriend Lori Diaz, which took place at the [[Grand Ole Opry|Grand Ole Opry House]] with [[Thompson Square]] giving a private performance of "Are You Gonna Kiss Me or Not."{{cite web|last=Pham|first=Thailan|title=The ''Biggest Loser's'' Vinny Hickerson Gets Engaged|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20550822,00.html|work=TV Watch|publisher=People.com|accessdate=5 April 2012|date=December 6, 2011}} The couple was married on October 11, 2012 (10-11-12) in Tennessee.{{cite web|last=Hanson|first=Scott|title=TRAILER CHOIR: Lose Some, Win Some|url=http://radiousa.com/blogs/post/shanson/2011/dec/07/country-music-news-12711/|work=Country Music News|publisher=RadioUSA.com|accessdate=5 April 2012}}{{cite web|title=Trailer Choir's Vinny Hickerson Gets Married|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/111414/trailer-choir-s-vinny-hickerson-gets-married|publisher=All Access Music Group|accessdate=15 October 2012|date=October 15, 2012}} Hickerson and Diaz divorced in May 2015.{{Cite web |last=Graham |first=Aimee |date=2016-02-21 |title=It's All About New Loves, New Music and Dear Memories with Trailer Choir |url=https://www.thecountrynote.com/interviews/its-all-about-new-loves-new-music-and-dear-memories-with-trailer-choir/ |access-date=2022-09-15 |website=The Country Note |language=en-US}} He later married a certified personal trainer named Jenny who is also a group fitness instructor, a third degree black belt, a 2012 World Champion in Taekwondo, and a bikini bodybuilder competitor.{{Citation |title=S1E2 {{!}} Vinny and Jenny Hickerson on Boundaries and Marriage {{!}} The Lauren Rainey Tenney Show |url=https://rumble.com/vbg9hh-s1e2-vinny-and-jenny-hickerson-on-boundaries-and-marriage-the-lauren-rainey.html |language=en |access-date=2022-09-15}} On September 12, 2017, his wife Jenny gave birth to a son, Jagger James Van-Zant Hickerson.{{Cite web |last=lafferlauren |date=2017-09-13 |title=Trailer Choir's Big Vinny is a Dad! |url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/trailer-choir-big-vinny-dad/ |access-date=2022-09-15 |website=Sounds Like Nashville}} Since being on ''The Biggest Loser'' Hickerson has been traveling around the country as a motivational speaker. He has been speaking mostly at churches because he says "I want to talk to the people who come from where I come from, the people who are down there fighting the battle every single day of life, that are trying to focus on the things they want."{{cite web|last=Morgan|first=Steven|title=Tearing Down the Walls Part 3: The Walls that We Build|url=http://destinycolumbia.podomatic.com/entry/2012-01-24T12_31_26-08_00|work=Tearing Down the Walls|publisher=Podomatic.com|accessdate=4 May 2012|format=Audio|date=January 22, 2012}} ===Crystal Hoyt=== On August 31, 2014, Crystal Hoyt married Todd Bray.{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Gayle|title=Trailer Choir's Crystal Hoyt Gets Married|url=http://theboot.com/crystal-hoyt-married/|website=The Boot|accessdate=16 August 2015}} On March 31, 2015, she gave birth to a son, Ryman Marshall Bray.{{cite web|last1=Thompson|first1=Gayle|title=Crystal Hoyt Bray Welcomes First Child|url=http://theboot.com/crystal-hoyt-bray-baby/|website=The Boot|accessdate=16 August 2015}} ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Album details ! colspan="2"| Peak chart

Director |- | 2008 ! scope="row"| "Off the Hillbilly Hook" | [[Michael Salomon]] |- | rowspan="2"| 2009 ! scope="row"| "Rockin' the Beer Gut" | The Brads |- ! scope="row"| "Rockin' the Beer Gut (Holla Day Version)" | Trailer Choir |- | 2010 ! scope="row"| "Rollin' Through the Sunshine" | Michael Salomon |- | 2016 ! scope="row"| "Ice Cold Summer" | |} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{commons category}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Musical groups established in 2006]] [[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 2016]] [[Category:Country music groups from Tennessee]] [[Category:Vocal trios]] [[Category:Show Dog-Universal Music artists]] [[Category:Average Joes Entertainment artists]]
